prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: G5
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We will use band 6 to search for detections in HCN(3-2), HCO+(3-2)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We aim to detect HCN and HCO+ lines simultaneously for 10 targets (and also 13CO(4-3) for two sources). These two lines should be of the same order of magnitude. Our targets are at redshifts 0.2 - 0.8, which limit our observations of HCN to either the transition 2-1, 3-2, 4-3 or 5-4, as shown in Table 1 in the proposal. We will observe five targets in band 4, and remaining five in Band 6.
Our targets are selected to be ULIRGs at z ~ 0.2 - 0.8 with strong CO(1-0) or CO(2-1) emission already detected by IRAM (Combes et al. 2011, 2013). Based on these CO(1-0) or CO(2-1) fluxes, we estimated the expected HCN line fluxes. We assumed a relatively high excitation for dense gas for our 10 ULIRGs, with (1) HCN(1-0)/CO(1-0)=HCN(2-1)/CO(2-1)=0.1; (2) HCN(2-1)/HCN(1-0)=2.5; (3) HCN(3-2)/HCN(1-0)=4.5; (4) HCN(4-3)/HCN(2-1)=2.5 ; (5) HCN(5-4)/HCN(2-1)=4. As listed in Table 1 in the proposal, the expected HCN fluxes ranges from 2.3-7.2mJy. These estimated fluxes set the required rms sensitivies we need for each target. To achieve the significant detections, we require a 50km/s velocity resolution, and a minimum SNR of 3 per velocity resolution element. With the FWHM of 250km/s for the lines, we should expect to have the total line detection SNR >= 3*sqrt(5) >=6.7.
We will use four spectral windows, with two spectral windows covering HCN and HCO+ lines, and other two windows covering continuum. We want to have the same angular resolution for all targets, thus we adapt the configuration accroding to the redshifts to achieve physical size of 3kpc synthesized beam. This means that we use angular resolution 1 arcseconds for targets at z~0.2-0.4, and 0.4 arcseconds for targets at z~0.6-0.8. We expect that dense molecular gas probed by HCN will be quite concentrated within 3\,kpc, so that the observation is a detection experiment. For three sources at z~ 0.6-0.8, Band 6 continuum observations will probe the cold dust emission at the rest-frame 500-600micron. With our specially designed 0.4arcsecond resolution, we should be able to resolve the far-IR emission region. Measurements on sizes and surface brightness of far-IR emission would be in complimentary with the measurement of dense molecular gas.
We will observe in dual polarization mode with 1.875 GHz total bandwidth per baseband, and pre-smoothed velocity resolution of 3.9 MHz (~ 8.6 km/s) for Band 4 and 7.8 MHz(~10 Km/s) for Band 6(FDM). The final smoothing resolution is 50km/s for all sources. We expect that the spatial extent of dense molecular gas in our targets are too small to be filtered out. We therefore do not require ACA observations.
In summary, we require 6.7 hours for 10 targets, including all overhead and calibrations.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: G12
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We will use band 6 to search for detections in HCN(3-2) and HCO+(3-2)

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 4 for HCN(2-1) and HCO+(2-1) + continuum

With our specially designed 0.4arcsecond resolution, we should be able to resolve the far-IR emission region. Measurements on sizes and surface brightness of far-IR emission would be in complimentary with the measurement of dense molecular gas.
We will observe in dual polarization mode with 1.875 GHz total bandwidth per baseband, and pre-smoothed velocity resolution of 3.9 MHz (~ 8.6 km/s) for Band 4 and 7.8 MHz(~10 Km/s) for Band 6(FDM). The final smoothing resolution is 50km/s for all sources. We expect that the spatial extent of dense molecular gas in our targets are too small to be filtered out. We therefore do not require ACA observations.
In summary, we require 6.7 hours for 10 targets, including all overhead and calibrations.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The relation between L(FIR) and molecular line luminosity L(mol) is a proxy to the Kennicutt-Schmidt law. Molecules such as HCN, HCO$^+$ and CS are excellent tracers of dense molecular gas with n~10^(5-8)cm^(-3), where star formation is taking place. The most significant finding from studies of HCN in nearby galaxies is that star formation efficiency, SFE(dense)=L(FIR)/L(HCN), is constant, from Galactic giant molecular clouds (GMC) to nearby normal star forming galaxies. This result seems to hold for HCN(1-0) and HCN(4-3). These studies have also revealed tantalizing evidence, suggesting that SFE(dense) and dense gas fraction L(HCN)/L(CO) may evolve as a function of luminosity and redshift. However, the number of existing high-z HCN detections is only 5, all at z>2. The statistics is too poor to be sure whether distant and more luminous galaxies really have higher SFE and more dense gas than that of z~0. We request 6.7hrs to obtain HCN observations for 10 ULIRGs at z~0.2-0.8 with strong CO emission. This will triple the number of existing high-z HCN detections, providing sufficient statistics for studies of dense molecular gas and star formation law well beyond the local Universe.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Infrared Processing and Analysis Center (IPAC), California Institute of Technology

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Observatorio de Madrid, Observatorio Astronómico Nacional
